column13: In keeping with our approach to collaborating and engaging with industry on climate-related issues, Coles has joined the Electric Vehicle Council (EVC). The EVC represents members from across the value chain of the electric vehicle sector and is focused on driving investment and awareness to accelerate the electrification of transport. Coles is also a member of the Climate Leaders Coalition, the Carbon Market Institute, the Australian Logistics Council and the Energy Users Association of Australia.
column20: Climate-Related Issues, Electric Vehicle Council (EVC), Driving Investment

column8: Partnership with Mart and Co Feedlot
column13: Progress has been made since partnering with Mort and Co Feedlot, the University of New England and DSM in two separate trials evaluating commercial feedlot performance, animal health and meat quality impacts from using the extensively studied methane-reducing supplement BovaerÃÂ®. Trial results were positive, with no adverse effects on feedlot performance, animal health or carcass attributes, providing us with the knowledge and confidence to use the supplement as an emissions reduction initiative. We are working with selected beef feedlots within our supply chain to include BovaerÃÂ® in their feeding programs.\t
column20: Mort and Co Feedlot, University of New England and DSM, Meet Quality Impacts, Emissions Reduction Initiative

column13: Through collaboration with DSM and Integrity Ag and Environment, we will be able to account for the reduction in methane emissions attributed to the use of BovaerÃÂ® in these feedlots through our Coles Finest Certified Carbon Neutral Beef program. In addition, for our Climate Active carbon-neutral beef certification, we piloted Climate ActiveÃ¢ÂÂs new draft guidelines for insetting carbon sequestered from trees planted on farms, helping to reduce net beef production emissions from farm to retail shelf.
column20: Climate Active Carbon Neutral Beef Certification, Climate Active, Trees Planted on Farms

column13: In 2021, the Allens commenced a three-year on-farm trial to identify the optimum pasture species and fertiliser application to build soil carbon. Building on that, Boorook Farm recently registered a soil carbon project with the Clean Energy Regulator, which aims to increase carbon in the soil by applying compost to improve pasture productivity, yield and soil organic matter.
column20: Allens, Three-Year on-farm Trial, Optimum Pasture Species

column13: Together, we are working on developing recycling services and bringing new waste technologies to market. Expanding our food waste services into stores in regional hubs of Bundaberg, Mildura, Townsville and Rockhampton, connecting local stores to food waste recycling services, diverting approximately 247.4 tonnes per year of food waste previously destined for landfill.
column20: Food Waste Services, Bundaberg, Mildura, Townsville, Recycling Services

column13: Together, we are working on developing recycling services and bringing new waste technologies to market. Commercial commingle services with stores in the Wollongong region to capture rigid plastic packaging, metal cans, containers and glass bottles, diverting approximately 17.5 tonnes per year away from landfills and into VisyÃ¢ÂÂs Smithfield material recycling facility.

column13: Together, we are working on developing recycling services and bringing new waste technologies to market. A service takes end-of-life store fittings and fixtures and separates materials for remanufacturing and recycling. Across four stores, the trial yielded 4.6 tonnes of metal and 0.4 tonnes of timber, all recycled.

column13: Together, we are working on developing recycling services and bringing new waste technologies to market. Switching the outer packaging on some cask wine ranges from non-recyclable shrink plastic wrap to recyclable cardboard packaging, saving 19 tonnes of plastic from entering landfills.
column20: Outer Packaging, Non-recyclable shrink plastic wrap, recyclable cardboard packaging

column13: Together, we are working on developing recycling services and bringing new waste technologies to market. Removal of all plastic bubble wraps across the liquor supply chain, saving 2.0 tonnes of plastic from entering landfills.
column20: Plastic Bubble Wrap, Liquor Supply Chain, Landfill

column13: Together, we are working on developing recycling services and bringing new waste technologies to market. Transitioning from plastic packaging tape to water-activated paper tape, saving 900km (2.0 tonnes) of plastic tape entering landfills.
column20: Water Activated Paper Tape, Plastic Tape, Landfill

column8: Light Weighting of Sparking Wine Bottles
column13: Together, we are working on developing recycling services and bringing new waste technologies to market. Lightweighting of sparkling wine bottles (a reduction of 100g of glass per bottle), removing 116 tonnes of glass.

column13: In FY23, more than 200 million drink containers, cans, cartons and bottles were returned to Coles-linked sites. It was since we started supporting the various state-based schemes in 2018, more than a billion containers have been replaced.

column13: As a founding signatory to the Australian Food Pact (the Pact), Coles has led industry commitment to food waste reduction. The Pact brings organisations across the food chain to identify and implement solutions to reduce food waste, supporting AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs target of halving food waste by 2030.

column13: In FY23, Coles measured food waste across more than 1,800 sites and stores nationally. Stop Food Waste Australia supported this measurement with data gaps and solutions identified, and it will be repeated annually to inform the actions Coles takes to reduce food waste.

column13: Coles is an active contributor to industry collaboration via Stop Food Waste AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs Food Rescue and Greenhouse Gas Working Groups, and it has played a vital role in the Horticulture Sector Plan. In Australia, 22%5 of food waste occurs in primary production (on farms). The Horticulture Sector Action Plan addresses food waste solutions across the supply chain that can support farmers, increase crop utilisation and reduce food waste.

column13: Atlas Soils in Mount Low, Queensland, will use a $490,000 Coles Nurture Fund grant to support an initiative that combines innovative technologies to track, store, recreate and redistribute food waste into various premium soil enhancement products for the region. This community-led project seeks to generate employment opportunities, minimise landfill waste and restore local soils' ecological health and productivity.
column20: Atlas Solis, Mount Low, Queensland, Premium Soil Enhancement

column13: Coles is a signatory to the Australian Packaging Covenant and a member of the Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation (APCO), tasked with facilitating the delivery of AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs 2025 National Packaging Targets1 (2025 Targets). column13: At the end of June 2023, we stopped selling plastic shopping bags in-store and online. It will remove 230 million plastic bags from circulation in one year. Our stores will continue to sell other reusable options, including paper bags that are FSCÃÂ® certified and made from 100% recycled fibre that can be recycled kerbside at the end of life.
